pullRequest.body:
In the current design of concrete categories in mathlib, there are two sources of `erw`s:

- Def-Eq abuse of `A ⟶ B` and `A →ₐ [R] B`: The type of `A ⟶ B` is by definition `A →ₐ[R] B`, but not at reducible transparency. So it happens that one `rw` lemma transforms a term in a form, where the next `rw` expects `A →ₐ B`. By supplying explicit `show` lines (copying the output of the pretty-printer), Lean correctly re-synthesizes the type to be `A →ₐ B` and the `rw` succeeds. This def-eq abuse hence always causes issues in the case where a lemma from the non-category theoretic part of the library should be applied. An insightful example is the following proof excerpt from current master (proof of `AlgebraCat.adj`):
```lean
import Mathlib.Algebra.Category.AlgebraCat.Basic
open CategoryTheory AlgebraCat
variable {R : Type u} [CommRing R]
set_option pp.analyze true

example : free.{u} R ⊣ forget (AlgebraCat.{u} R) :=
  Adjunction.mkOfHomEquiv
    { homEquiv := fun _ _ => (FreeAlgebra.lift _).symm
      homEquiv_naturality_left_symm := by
        intro X Y Z f g
        apply FreeAlgebra.hom_ext
        ext x
        simp only [Equiv.symm_symm, Function.comp_apply, free_map]
        /- Eq (α := Z)
             (((FreeAlgebra.lift R) (f ≫ g) :
               Prefunctor.obj (Functor.toPrefunctor (free R)) X ⟶ Z) (FreeAlgebra.ι R x) : ↑Z) _
        -/
        erw [FreeAlgebra.lift_ι_apply]
        sorry
      homEquiv_naturality_right := sorry }
```
The `simp` lemma `FreeAlgebra.lift_ι_apply` expects an `AlgHom`, but as the `pp.analyze` shows, the type is synthesized as a `⟶`. With a show line before the `erw`, Lean correctly synthesizes the type as an `AlgHom` again and the `rw` succeeds. The solution is to strictly distinguish between `A ⟶ B` and `A →ₐ[R] B`: We define a new `AlgebraCat.Hom` structure with a single field `hom : A →ₐ[R] B`. The above proof is mostly solved by `ext; simp` then, except for the `ext` lemma `FreeAlgebra.hom_ext` not applying. This is because now the type is `AlgebraCat.of R (FreeAlgebra R X) →ₐ[R] _` and Lean can't see through the `AlgebraCat.of` at reducible transparency. Hence the solution is to make `AlgebraCat.of` an `abbrev`. Finally, the proof is `by ext; simp` or even `by aesop`.

- `FunLike`: An intermediate design adapted the changes from the first point, but with keeping a `FunLike` and an `AlgHomClass` instance on `A ⟶ B`. This lead to many additional `coe` lemmas for composition of morphisms, where it mattered which of the three appearing terms of `AlgebraCat` where of the form `AlgebraCat.of R A`. Eric Wieser suggested to replace the `FunLike` by a `CoeFun` which is inlined, so an invocation of `f x` turns into `f.hom x`. This has then worked very smoothly.

So the key points are:
- Homs in concrete categories should be one-field structures to maintain a strict type distinction.
- Use `CoeFun` instead of `FunLike`, since the latter is automatically inlined.
- Make `.of` constructors an `abbrev` to obtain the def-eq `↑(AlgebraCat.of R A) = A` at reducible transparency.

For more details, see the [Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Fixing.20the.20.60erw.60.20hell.20around.20concrete.20categories).

---

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I am now happy with this benchmark. The +1.2% in `lint` is gone. The increase in instructions in the `Basic` file is mostly because it became longer, the increase in the `Limits` file is because synthesizing `MulHomClass` and friends from an `AlgHom` is slow independently of this change. A possible fix is to restore `AlgHom.map_{mul,add,one,zero}`. One of the above benchmarks confirms that this significantly decreases build time again.

Let's just do another bench

!bench

> This is a really nice improvement in readability! I'm a bit worried about the slowdowns, since 30% / 10^10 instructions is a lot. Although they seem to be limited to the two files where you changed quite a lot of proofs, so I would be definitely willing to exchange performance hit for a lot more readability. I'll look into the exact reason for the slowdown and see if we can't reduce the impact to maybe 10% or so.
> 
> Do you have any idea how much of the 30% slowdown came from the addition of the `examples` that are now in the separate test file?

I think the main slow down in the `Limits` file is because synthesizing `MulHomClass` and friends from an `AlgHom` is slow independently of this change. I did a test yesterday, replacing `map_ {mul,add,zero,one}` with `AlgHom.map_{mul,add,zero,one}` and the slowdown went back to +4.143⬝10⁹ instructions (+7 %).
See this benchmark: http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/3592a324-de1b-439e-81e0-6f7ffafff991/to/f0f48a65-728f-47e7-b2fe-0306f6125b93

Another slowdown came from applying Mathews suggestion (commit [73bd116](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19065/commits/73bd116cac758d97fcf496dcaa1c339a90e2fce7)), see the benchmark http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/3592a324-de1b-439e-81e0-6f7ffafff991/to/3eaba5eb-93a3-4810-858e-594e1aed06f5 here.

> I think the main slow down in the `Limits` file is because synthesizing `MulHomClass` and friends from an `AlgHom` is slow independently of this change. I did a test yesterday, replacing `map_ {mul,add,zero,one}` with `AlgHom.map_{mul,add,zero,one}` and the slowdown went back to +4.143⬝10⁹ instructions (+7 %). See this benchmark: http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/3592a324-de1b-439e-81e0-6f7ffafff991/to/f0f48a65-728f-47e7-b2fe-0306f6125b93

Looking through `Limits.lean`, it appears many declarations got about 5%-10% slower to typecheck, which I think is fine, but the real issue is indeed instance synthesis in `limitConeIsLimit`. It seems to be a bit more subtle though: the extra time comes from *failing* inference of `ZeroHomClass` and `AddHomClass` on an `Equiv`. Namely, at some point the simplifier encounters something of type `(Shrink.{w, max w v} ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections ≃ ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections)` applied to `0`, tries to find a `ZeroHomClass` instance for it, and fails only after half a second. The same for `AddHomClass` in the other goal. Unfortunately there is no way yet to make instance synthesis fail faster in situations where we have a big hierarchy.

But there is a sneaky workaround!
With my suggestions I believe that the slowdown will be there, but at least quite limited in impact and we get much better looking proofs in results. So this looks good to me now, thanks!

Can you update your PR description to explain the changes and reasoning for posterity? 

Let's also do one more run of benchmarking.
!bench

> Can you update your PR description to explain the changes and reasoning for posterity?
> 
> Let's also do one more run of benchmarking. I think I am satisfied.

What is needed to get this merged? For the slowdown: When replacing every `aesop` by a variation of `by ext; simp`, on my machine the build time for the `Basic` file goes from 5.69 s to 3.00 s while master is at 2.94 s. So the slowdown is only caused by replacing explicit proofs by automation, which I think is good and I would accept the slowdown in exchange. Do you agree?
I agree that the slowdown is a worthy tradeoff. So I still stand by my desire to merge this. @mattrobball, what do you think?

Since Matt gave this a thumbs up, let's get this merged. Thank you so much for this work and your nice results!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12007117537/job/33467047623)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12007117537/job/33467048243)

This is a really nice improvement in readability! I'm a bit worried about the slowdowns, since 30% / 10^10 instructions is a lot. Although they seem to be limited to the two files where you changed quite a lot of proofs, so I would be definitely willing to exchange performance hit for a lot more readability. I'll look into the exact reason for the slowdown and see if we can't reduce the impact to maybe 10% or so.

Do you have any idea how much of the 30% slowdown came from the addition of the `examples` that are now in the separate test file?

Things would probably improve if you used 
```lean
comp := fun ⟨f⟩ ⟨g⟩ => ⟨g.comp f⟩
```
and below as necessary.
In general, if you are willing to use the anonymous constructor notation is some spots, you can more cleanly preserve API boundaries and still get the automation you want.
Changed, I _think_ I found all of them, but if not, please say so.
Locally, it does not seem to make a difference, but I only know how to measure build time, not instruction count.

I don't necessarily think it will help with performance much. The main thing is that Lean can choke on eta reduction when it is deep enough in a term so it is less problematic theoretically to avoid the extra eta expansions. But perhaps. 

I think the main performance penalty is a lot of failed simp unification attempts.

The main slowdown seems to come from synthesizing `MulHomClass` etc. around L103 of `AlgebraCat.Limits`. Using the deprecated `AlgHom.map_mul` and friends as a shortcut gets build time roughly back to the `FunLike` version.
Why was the suggestion reverted?
Because it caused a slowdown of another +4⬝10⁹ instructions and because I wanted to get numbers for the `map_mul` -> `AlgHom.map_mul` change independently of your suggestion.
Happy to revert the revert if you think it is better, but it seems strange to me that performance got worse.

I think it is more a symptom of problems with the current design - like the too generic lemmas - than anything else. Writing out eta expanded terms when unnecessary is inadvisable. I would prefer it be avoided here.
Okay, re-applied the commit.

You might be able to use
```suggestion
structure AlgebraCat where of ::
```
here, and then drop `of` below. Fine to leave to a follow-up PR though.
Ah, this doesn't work because unfortunately `R` is implicit. Maybe @kmill knows if there's any syntax for overriding argument implicitness in constructors, or if any is planned.
Is `of ::` any different (ignoring the wrong variable implicitness) from the independent `AlgCat.of` other than saving some lines?
It saves having two identical functions (your current version means `mk ::`), which can be annoying if the wrong one ends up in your goal state.
Ah, I forgot about the `.mk` constructor.

> Ah, this doesn't work because unfortunately `R` is implicit. Maybe @kmill knows if there's any syntax for overriding argument implicitness in constructors, or if any is planned.

This seems like it should be filed with core. There is clearly value in forcing the user to write `R`. We don't want Lean to initiate a search over all `R` that might make `A` into an `Algebra R A`.
At the least, `mk` should be `private` to avoid users introducing it and the doc-string of `of` should say something about it being the preferred constructor for `AlgebraCat`.
How do I make the automatically generated constructor private?

```lean
structure foo where 
  private mk :: 
```
Thanks, done.

Similarly,
```suggestion
structure Hom (A B : AlgebraCat.{v} R) where ofHom ::
```
might let you drop `ofHom` below.
This does seem to produce `Hom.ofHom` which is undesirable. Tricking it with `_root_.AlgebraCat.ofHom ::` also does not work.

The `export` command allows you to remove the `Hom` namespace, something like:
```lean
namespace AlgebraCat

export Hom (hom)

end AlgebraCat
```

(untested)
Thanks, this works. But I realized a different problem, namely: `ofHom` is not `Hom.mk` because `ofHom` explicitly produces something of the form `of R A \hom of R B`.

Good point!

Note for myself to check: `(of A : Type*)` does not unify with `A` at reducible transparency, right?

Indeed:

```
example {R A : Type u} [CommRing R] [Ring A] [Algebra R A] : (of R A : Type u) = A := by
  fail_if_success with_reducible rfl -- Not reducibly defeq
  rfl -- But they are defeq.
```
Should we make `AlgebraCat.of` an `abbrev` then? This would fix the `ext` issue.

In my mind, API boundaries in category theory should be a semipermeable membrane where we easily flow into the concrete types themselves but it is hard to flow from them to objects and morphisms. So I think an `abbrev` is reasonable.
That might be a good idea, because then `↑(of R X) = ↑⟨X⟩ = X` is a (reducible) definitional equality. I'll see if that causes any downstream breakage...
I checked, mathlib still builds with the `abbrev`
It does conflict with Eric's suggestion above though. In theory, if `of` is actually the constructor, then it should be eta reduced away at reducible transparency.

And it allows for a lot of proofs to be entirely automated! Feel free to cherry-pick commit [`250bef56`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/250bef56683a482ea81c4024f54910df376a5bee) :)
I raced you :) but you spotted some more golfs

> It does conflict with Eric's suggestion above though. In theory, if `of` is actually the constructor, then it should be eta reduced away at reducible transparency.

Exactly, so if we can't figure out how to make `R` explicit in `mk` then `abbrev of` would be the alternative.
So `coe_of` now can't be a `simp` lemma anymore, but this is sensible, because `dsimp only` already solves `↑(of R A) = A`.
Should `ofHom` also get the same treatment?

Ideally we could do something like
```lean
structure Hom' {R : Type*} [CommRing R] (A : Type u) (B : Type v) [Ring A] [Ring B] [Algebra R A]
    [Algebra R B] where
  ofHom :: 
  hom : A →ₐ[R] B 

instance : Category (AlgebraCat.{v} R) where 
  Hom := fun ⟨A⟩ ⟨B⟩ => Hom' A B
  id := fun ⟨A⟩ => ⟨AlgHom.id R A⟩
  comp := fun ⟨f⟩ ⟨g⟩ => ⟨g.comp f⟩
```
but Lean cannot find the ring instance on `A` or `B` when destructuring
Also ideally we could use the patterns on the left hand side of the fields.
I don't think we should be using pattern matches here, as they generate worse terms.
In my experience, the support for `match` reduction exceeds that of eta expansions.
See [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/270676-lean4/topic/optimal.20instance.20design.20for.20structure.20wrappers) for an example. Feel free to disabuse me of this belief.
Here

`toHom` or `toAlgHom` might be a better name, which matches `QuadraticModuleCat.toIsometry`; though we can of course rename that one instead.

Perhaps a zulip poll for how to name these is sensible?
Started [a zulip poll](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Fixing.20the.20.60erw.60.20hell.20around.20concrete.20categories/near/483148460)
The poll has a slight favor for `.hom` so I went with that.
This should be in the test library with `import Mathlib` to guard against problems downstream of the module. If you wanted to keep it fast, you could also limit heartbeats there.
Moved to `MathlibTest` and limited the heartbeats to 10k. Is this reasonable?

I'd like to figure out how/if we can replace this proof with a one-line `aesop` call. I remember having to apply `FreeAlgebra.hom_ext` manually was also because of some defeq problem, so that can hopefully be fixed now!

This does not seem easily fixable without copying over a lot of `ext` lemmas: `FreeAlgebra.hom_ext` expects maps of the type `FreeAlgebra ?R ?X →ₐ[?R] ?A`, but we actually get:

```
  ↑({ obj := fun S ↦ AlgebraCat.of R (FreeAlgebra R S),
            map := fun {X Y} f ↦ AlgebraCat.ofHom ((FreeAlgebra.lift R) (FreeAlgebra.ι R ∘ f)) }.obj
        X) →ₐ[R]
    ↑({ obj := fun S ↦ AlgebraCat.of R (FreeAlgebra R S),
            map := fun {X Y} f ↦ AlgebraCat.ofHom ((FreeAlgebra.lift R) (FreeAlgebra.ι R ∘ f)) }.obj
        X)
```
I *think* we could try unification hints, but I certainly don't expect that to be part of this PR.

This definition went from taking 0.13s to 0.86s to elaborate on my machine. it looks like a lot of this is `simp`: replacing all `simp`s with `simp only` brings it back down to 0.36s, which becomes 0.21s if we also make it a `noncomputable` def. Note that the heartbeats are still very low: only 27628 (where 200000 is the maximum).

I think it should be fine to accept this slowdown, so I am happy with the performance of this file.

We could make this:
```suggestion
        ext
```

if we add the following lemma after `free`:
```lean
open FreeAlgebra in
/-- See note [partially-applied ext lemmas]. -/
@[ext high]
theorem free.hom_ext {R X : Type u} {A : Type*} [CommRing R] [Semiring A]
    [Algebra R A] {f g : (free R).obj X →ₐ[R] A}
    (w : (f : FreeAlgebra R X → A) ∘ ι R = (g : FreeAlgebra R X → A) ∘ ι R) : f = g :=
  FreeAlgebra.hom_ext w
```
But I don't think that's worth the effort unless we do that systematically. So this could be left to a follow-up PR.

This also works
```
ext : 1
dsimp
ext
simp
```
but we need the intermediate `dsimp`. (edited: mixed up the order)
I see! Still not really an improvement, so I think we can leave it as is.

Since `map_mul` will be the very last thing that `simp` does, and we follow it by a `rfl`, we could also do this:
```suggestion
    simp only [Functor.comp_obj, forget_obj, Equiv.toFun_as_coe, Functor.mapCone_pt,
      Functor.mapCone_π_app, forget_map, Equiv.symm_apply_apply,
      Types.Small.limitCone_pt, equivShrink_symm_mul]
    apply map_mul
```

These three suggestions will reduce the time taken on my machine for this definition from 2.5s to 1.5s (with 1.3s on `master`).
Aha, I had not realized that it was because of failing instance synthesis. How did you spot that? Did you look at the instance synthesis trace?

So what I did was `set_option trace.profiler true`, which will show you trace messages for all the elaboration steps that take a lot of time. Then I unfold the trace message with the highest amount of time, and after unfolding quite a few levels of nesting we get to:
```
  [] [0.546658] simp only [Functor.comp_obj, forget_obj, Equiv.toFun_as_coe, Functor.mapCone_pt, Functor.mapCone_π_app,
      forget_map, map_add, Equiv.symm_apply_apply, Types.Small.limitCone_pt, equivShrink_symm_add] ▼
  [Meta.synthInstance] [0.040063] ✅️ AddHomClass (↑s.pt →ₐ[R] ↑(F.obj j)) ↑s.pt ↑(F.obj j) ▶
  [Meta.synthInstance] [0.377691] ❌️ AddHomClass
      (Shrink.{w, max w v} ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections ≃
        ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections)
      (Shrink.{w, max w v} ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections)
      ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections ▶
```
where the `❌️` means this search fails to find an instance (but did not otherwise error). So that seems to be the issue.

(Also I remembered from when I edited the `FunLike` hierarchy a while back that it was usually failing synthesis that caused timeouts, not the successes.)
Are there more specifically keyed version of these generic morphism lemmas?
Thanks @Vierkantor, this is very helpful!

> Are there more specifically keyed version of these generic morphism lemmas?

Yep, `AlgHom.map_{add,mul,zero}` still exist (but are deprecated). See also the benchmark above commit `2be0806` where Chris showed that using the specific versions gets rid of the slowdown.
Would a `simproc` that detects either `AlgHom` or more generally a morphism in category be reasonable?

```suggestion
    simp only [Functor.comp_obj, forget_obj, Equiv.toFun_as_coe, Functor.mapCone_pt,
      Functor.mapCone_π_app, forget_map, Equiv.symm_apply_apply,
      equivShrink_symm_zero]
    apply map_zero
```

```suggestion
    simp only [Functor.comp_obj, forget_obj, Equiv.toFun_as_coe, Functor.mapCone_pt,
      Functor.mapCone_π_app, forget_map, Equiv.symm_apply_apply,
      Types.Small.limitCone_pt, equivShrink_symm_add]
    apply map_add
```
Maybe synthesis heartbeats also. As to the precise bounds, I'm not sure.
Done.
Great!
Let's make this an `abbrev` also for now.
I am just checking if it builds locally.
And should I also make `Hom.mk` private?

Sorry for the double post. Unsure if it got lost in me yelling at the clouds. 

Yeah, let's make it private also

I claim this was better as
```suggestion
  comp := fun  f g ↦ f.hom.comp g.hom
```
as it avoids inducing `match` terms into the expression (and throughout). I think @mattrobball suggested the opposite though.
Yes, this was the original version and the change caused slowdowns, which I had reverted and then restored upon request by Matthew.
I think `simp` has better support for `match` reduction than for eta reduction in situations like this. I linked to a thread on Zulip with a basic example.
Does this better (automatic) `simp` support really matter though in a situation where we supply the relevant `simp` lemmas anyway?
Not having to always provide "obvious" simp lemmas seems a worthwhile goal.
Agreed, here we have them though. I don't have a strong opinion on this, the only empirical evidence for me is the (mild) slowdown favoring the original version.

> I linked to a thread on Zulip with a basic example.

Would you mind repeating the link here?
It is this one: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/270676-lean4/topic/optimal.20instance.20design.20for.20structure.20wrappers

I think the conclusion in that thread is wrong; what's going on is that the `congrArg` is forcing the `match` to be unfolded, which ends up being more aggressive than in the non-`match` case. The `simp` is a red herring.

While the "`congrArg` forces unfolding everywhere" approach is cute, I don't think it's a substitute for "actually writing the `val_all` lemmas", and once you have those lemmas then `dsimp` has you covered for the unfolding.
Given I took that from something already broken in category theory, I am still concerned but I won't stand in the way if everyone else wants the other term.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor(Algebra/Category): turn homs in `AlgebraCat` into a structure

```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

|-|-:|:-:|

I am now happy with this benchmark. The +1.2% in `lint` is gone. The increase in instructions in the `Basic` file is mostly because it became longer, the increase in the `Limits` file is because synthesizing `MulHomClass` and friends from an `AlgHom` is slow independently of this change. A possible fix is to restore `AlgHom.map_{mul,add,one,zero}`. One of the above benchmarks confirms that this significantly decreases build time again.

This is a really nice improvement in readability! I'm a bit worried about the slowdowns, since 30% / 10^10 instructions is a lot. Although they seem to be limited to the two files where you changed quite a lot of proofs, so I would be definitely willing to exchange performance hit for a lot more readability. I'll look into the exact reason for the slowdown and see if we can't reduce the impact to maybe 10% or so.

Do you have any idea how much of the 30% slowdown came from the addition of the `examples` that are now in the separate test file?

Let's just do another bench

!bench

> This is a really nice improvement in readability! I'm a bit worried about the slowdowns, since 30% / 10^10 instructions is a lot. Although they seem to be limited to the two files where you changed quite a lot of proofs, so I would be definitely willing to exchange performance hit for a lot more readability. I'll look into the exact reason for the slowdown and see if we can't reduce the impact to maybe 10% or so.
> 
> Do you have any idea how much of the 30% slowdown came from the addition of the `examples` that are now in the separate test file?

I think the main slow down in the `Limits` file is because synthesizing `MulHomClass` and friends from an `AlgHom` is slow independently of this change. I did a test yesterday, replacing `map_ {mul,add,zero,one}` with `AlgHom.map_{mul,add,zero,one}` and the slowdown went back to +4.143⬝10⁹ instructions (+7 %).
See this benchmark: http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/3592a324-de1b-439e-81e0-6f7ffafff991/to/f0f48a65-728f-47e7-b2fe-0306f6125b93

Another slowdown came from applying Mathews suggestion (commit [73bd116](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19065/commits/73bd116cac758d97fcf496dcaa1c339a90e2fce7)), see the benchmark http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/3592a324-de1b-439e-81e0-6f7ffafff991/to/3eaba5eb-93a3-4810-858e-594e1aed06f5 here.

> I think the main slow down in the `Limits` file is because synthesizing `MulHomClass` and friends from an `AlgHom` is slow independently of this change. I did a test yesterday, replacing `map_ {mul,add,zero,one}` with `AlgHom.map_{mul,add,zero,one}` and the slowdown went back to +4.143⬝10⁹ instructions (+7 %). See this benchmark: http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/3592a324-de1b-439e-81e0-6f7ffafff991/to/f0f48a65-728f-47e7-b2fe-0306f6125b93

Looking through `Limits.lean`, it appears many declarations got about 5%-10% slower to typecheck, which I think is fine, but the real issue is indeed instance synthesis in `limitConeIsLimit`. It seems to be a bit more subtle though: the extra time comes from *failing* inference of `ZeroHomClass` and `AddHomClass` on an `Equiv`. Namely, at some point the simplifier encounters something of type `(Shrink.{w, max w v} ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections ≃ ↑(F ⋙ CategoryTheory.forget (AlgebraCat R)).sections)` applied to `0`, tries to find a `ZeroHomClass` instance for it, and fails only after half a second. The same for `AddHomClass` in the other goal. Unfortunately there is no way yet to make instance synthesis fail faster in situations where we have a big hierarchy.

But there is a sneaky workaround!
With my suggestions I believe that the slowdown will be there, but at least quite limited in impact and we get much better looking proofs in results. So this looks good to me now, thanks!

Can you update your PR description to explain the changes and reasoning for posterity? 

Let's also do one more run of benchmarking.

What is needed to get this merged? For the slowdown: When replacing every `aesop` by a variation of `by ext; simp`, on my machine the build time for the `Basic` file goes from 5.69 s to 3.00 s while master is at 2.94 s. So the slowdown is only caused by replacing explicit proofs by automation, which I think is good and I would accept the slowdown in exchange. Do you agree?
I agree that the slowdown is a worthy tradeoff. So I still stand by my desire to merge this. @mattrobball, what do you think?

Since Matt gave this a thumbs up, let's get this merged. Thank you so much for this work and your nice results!
